overview: A foundational course targeting the essential Grades 3–5 skills that every student must own before middle school succeeds. Covers whole number operations (addition through long division), fraction concepts and operations, decimal fluency, basic geometry and measurement, data interpretation, and early algebraic thinking. Designed for students with elementary gaps — whether they're preparing for 6th grade, catching up mid-year, or building confidence. Diagnostic-first: find what's broken, fix it, prove it's fixed.
naturalProgression: Diagnose number sense gaps: place value, rounding, estimation, basic fact fluency
Lock in multi-digit addition and subtraction with regrouping
Build multiplication fluency through 12×12 and multi-digit multiplication
Master division facts and long division with interpreting remainders
Understand fractions as parts, equivalence, and comparison
Add, subtract, and multiply fractions with unlike denominators
Read, compare, and compute with decimals; connect to fractions
Calculate perimeter, area, angles, and classify shapes
Interpret graphs, extend patterns, and use unknowns
Prove readiness for 6th-grade math with cumulative mastery

aiInstructionModel.approach: AI-led gradual release with concrete-pictorial-abstract progression
aiInstructionModel.description: The AI tutor leads instruction using the CPA model — every concept starts with something you can touch or see (manipulatives, drawings, real objects), moves to pictures and diagrams (bar models, area models, number lines), then formalizes to numbers and symbols. This course serves students who may have math anxiety or gaps from earlier grades, so pacing is patient, success is celebrated, and mistakes are treated as information, not failure.

phases.aiRole: Introduce the concept with a concrete, hands-on context. Use familiar objects (pizza slices, money, blocks, sports). Activate whatever the student DOES know before building new knowledge.
phases.studentRole: Connect to personal experience, identify what they already know, engage with the scenario

phases.aiRole: Walk through 2-3 examples step by step. Use pictures and diagrams alongside numbers. Narrate the WHY behind each step, not just the how. Keep language simple and direct.
phases.studentRole: Follow along, watch the steps, notice the pattern, ask questions

phases.aiRole: Present guided problems with scaffolding. Ask one question at a time. Give hints that redirect thinking rather than revealing the answer. Celebrate correct steps, not just final answers.
phases.studentRole: Try each step, explain thinking out loud, accept feedback, try again if needed

phases.aiRole: Assign independent practice at the right difficulty level. Include a mix of computation and word problems. Require showing work.
phases.studentRole: Solve independently, show work, check answers, build confidence

phases.aiRole: Short check: 3-5 problems. Assess both accuracy and strategy. If fluent, advance. If not, reteach the specific gap before moving on.

aiDecisionRights: Adjust difficulty dynamically — if a student can't do 3-digit subtraction, drop back to 2-digit before proceeding
Use age-appropriate contexts: younger students (8-10) respond to games, animals, food, sports, school scenarios
Be patient with fact fluency — some students need repeated practice with multiplication tables, and that's OK
Use visual models (number lines, area models, fraction strips) until the student demonstrates they're ready for abstract
Celebrate small wins — 'You got that right! You just divided a 3-digit number' builds math identity
Never say 'this is easy' — what's easy for one student is terrifying for another

nonNegotiableThreads: Multiplication and division fact fluency (the engine for everything)
Fraction understanding (not just procedures — what does 3/4 MEAN?)
Place value fluency (decimals and whole numbers)
Word problem comprehension (read, identify, set up, solve, check)
Estimation habit (predict before computing, check reasonableness after)

aiGuidanceNotes: This course serves students who may be behind, anxious, or both. Every interaction should build math confidence alongside math skill. Never assume a student 'should' know something — if they don't, teach it without judgment. Use the CPA model rigorously: concrete objects first (blocks, coins, food), then pictures/diagrams, then symbols. Fact fluency (especially multiplication) is the single biggest lever — students who don't know their facts will struggle with fractions, division, and everything that follows. Be patient, be encouraging, and celebrate progress.
